ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We explored different theoretical approaches to 'context' in the traditions of philosophy of language and formal linguistics. We then explored different empirical problems, putting those approaches to test, and finally arrived to the conclusion that we needed a dynamic semantics approach to have a proper treatment of some phenomena.
I very much enjoyed learning about approaches to language from a philosophical perspective. It helped me understand some core concepts in semantics and the discussions were extremely helpful.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is excellent, I cannot think right now of a way of improving it.

I enjoyed the small size of the class, which encouraged good discussions. Sometimes, the number of readings was too much to keep up with, and I am glad Zoltan always provided some background and context to the readings. The handouts were very helpful as well!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, specially is you are interested in the interaction between language and philosophy (especially philosophy of meaning).
